pat/stop-loss-placement-for-price-action.name: Stop Loss Placement for Price Action Patterns
pat/stop-loss-placement-for-price-action.description: | Pattern | Stop Loss Placement | |---------|-------------------| | Pin Bar | Above/below the long tail | | Engulfing Bar | Above/below the candlestick pattern | | Inside Bar | Above/below the mother candle | | Inside Bar False Breakout | Above/below the break bar |

pat/the-engulfing-bar-pattern.name: The Engulfing Bar Pattern
pat/the-engulfing-bar-pattern.description: The Engulfing Bar is formed when a candle fully engulfs the previous candle. The engulfing bar can engulf more than one previous candle, but at least one candle must be fully consumed. This pattern consists of two bodies where the second body engulfs the first.

pat/bearish-engulfing.name: Bearish Engulfing
pat/bearish-engulfing.description: - The first body is smaller than the second one; the second body engulfs the previous one. - This pattern tells us that **sellers are in control** of the market. - When it occurs at the end of an **uptrend**, it indicates that buyers are engulfed by sellers, signaling a **trend reversal**. - You can

pat/bullish-engulfing.name: Bullish Engulfing
pat/bullish-engulfing.description: - The bullish engulfing bar consists of two candlesticks: a small body followed by the engulfing candle. - This pattern tells us that the market is no longer under control of sellers, and **buyers will take control**. - When it forms in the context of an **uptrend**, it indicates a **continuation si

pat/the-doji-pattern.name: The Doji Pattern
pat/the-doji-pattern.description: The Doji is one of the most important Japanese candlestick patterns. When this candlestick forms, it tells us that the market opens and closes at the same price, indicating **equality and indecision** between buyers and sellers. No one is in control of the market.

pat/the-dragonfly-doji-pattern.name: The Dragonfly Doji Pattern
pat/the-dragonfly-doji-pattern.description: The Dragonfly Doji is a **bullish** candlestick pattern formed when the open, high, and close are the same or about the same price. It is characterized by a **long lower tail** that shows resistance from buyers and their attempt to push the market up.

pat/the-gravestone-doji-pattern.name: The Gravestone Doji Pattern
pat/the-gravestone-doji-pattern.description: The Gravestone Doji is the **bearish version** of the Dragonfly Doji. It is formed when the open and close are the same or about the same price. It is characterized by a **long upper tail**.

pat/the-morning-star-pattern.name: The Morning Star Pattern
pat/the-morning-star-pattern.description: The Morning Star is a **bullish reversal pattern** that often occurs at the bottom of a downtrend. It consists of three candlesticks:

pat/the-evening-star-pattern.name: The Evening Star Pattern
pat/the-evening-star-pattern.description: The Evening Star is a **bearish reversal pattern** that usually occurs at the top of an uptrend. It is the bearish version of the Morning Star. It consists of three candlesticks:

pat/the-hammer.name: The Hammer
pat/the-hammer.description: The Hammer candlestick is created when the open, high, and close are roughly the same price. It is characterized by a **long lower shadow** that indicates bullish rejection from buyers and their intention to push the market higher.

pat/the-shooting-star.name: The Shooting Star
pat/the-shooting-star.description: The Shooting Star is formed when the open, low, and close are roughly the same price. It is characterized by a **small body and a long upper shadow**. It is the bearish version of the Hammer.

pat/the-harami-pattern.name: The Harami Pattern
pat/the-harami-pattern.description: The Harami pattern (meaning "pregnant" in Japanese) is considered both a **reversal and continuation pattern**. It consists of two candlesticks:

pat/tweezers-top.name: Tweezers Top
pat/tweezers-top.description: The Tweezers Top formation is a **bearish reversal pattern** seen at the top of an uptrend. - Consists of two candlesticks: a bullish candlestick followed by a bearish candlestick. - Occurs during an uptrend when buyers push the price higher, giving the impression the market is still going up, but s

pat/tweezers-bottom.name: Tweezers Bottom
pat/tweezers-bottom.description: The Tweezers Bottom formation is a **bullish reversal pattern** seen at the bottom of a downtrend. - Consists of two candlesticks: a bearish candlestick followed by a bullish candlestick. - Happens during a downtrend when sellers push the market lower, but the next session price closes above or roug

pat/what-is-an-engulfing-bar-pattern.name: What is an Engulfing Bar Pattern?
pat/what-is-an-engulfing-bar-pattern.description: This reversal candlestick pattern consists of two opposite colored bodies in which the second body engulfs or covers entirely the first one. - A **bullish engulfing pattern** forms at the end of a downtrend. It provides a clear signal that buying pressure has overwhelmed selling pressure. The buyers

pat/how-to-trade-the-engulfing-bar-three.name: How to Trade the Engulfing Bar: Three Elements

pat/money-management-rules-for-engulfing.name: Money Management Rules for Engulfing Bar Trades
pat/money-management-rules-for-engulfing.description: Not all engulfing bar patterns are worth trading. Price action signals with low risk/reward ratios should be ignored.

pat/what-is-an-inside-bar.name: What is an Inside Bar?
pat/what-is-an-inside-bar.japanese_name: completely contained by the first one
pat/what-is-an-inside-bar.description: An inside bar is two candlesticks: - **First candle:** Called the **mother candle** -- it is big and large. - **Second candle:** Smaller and located **inside** of the mother bar (completely contained by the first one). This is the **opposite** of the engulfing bar pattern.

pat/psychology-behind-the-pattern-format.name: Psychology Behind the Pattern Formation
pat/psychology-behind-the-pattern-format.description: The inside bar formation indicates a **period of consolidation**. - **In a bullish trend:** It reflects that the bulls are not buying any further on the second day. It is represented by a small black candle on the second day after a strong uptrend. - **In a bearish trend:** It means that sellers are

pat/how-to-trade-inside-bars-in-trending.name: How to Trade Inside Bars in Trending Markets
pat/how-to-trade-inside-bars-in-trending.description: The inside bar can be traded successfully in trending markets, particularly when the market is moving strongly.

pat/trading-inside-bars-with-support-and.name: Trading Inside Bars with Support and Resistance
pat/trading-inside-bars-with-support-and.description: Support and resistance levels represent a psychological level where the game is played between buyers and sellers.

pat/inside-bar-as-confirmation.name: Inside Bar as Confirmation
pat/inside-bar-as-confirmation.description: - When you see a broken support level with bears in control, the inside bar pattern gives you the **right time to enter**. - The formation of an inside bar after a breakout signals **indecision** in the market. - If you sell immediately after the breakout (aggressive entry), it is tricky because the

pat/tips-on-trading-inside-bar-setups.name: Tips on Trading Inside Bar Setups

pat/trading-the-false-breakout-of-the-in.name: Trading the False Breakout of the Inside Bar

pat/what-is-an-inside-bar-false-breakout.name: What is an Inside Bar False Breakout?
pat/what-is-an-inside-bar-false-breakout.description: This price action signal is formed when price breaks out from the inside bar pattern and then **quickly reverses to close within the range of the mother bar**.

pat/inside-bar-false-breakout-trading-ex.name: Inside Bar False Breakout Trading Examples

pat/benefits-of-trading-the-inside-bar-f.name: Benefits of Trading the Inside Bar False Breakout
pat/benefits-of-trading-the-inside-bar-f.description: 1. **Stay away from trapped traders** and enter the market when novice traders have to exit with a loss. 2. **Great risk/reward potential:** When big participants surprise amateurs and take their money, the market moves very strongly. You can risk 50 points for 400 points profit. 3. **Predict proper

pat/pin-bar-anatomy.name: Pin Bar Anatomy
pat/pin-bar-anatomy.description: A pin bar is a chart candlestick characterized by a **very long tail** that shows rejection and indicates that the market will move in the opposite direction. - The area between the open and close is called the **real body**. Typically all pin bars have a very small real body and a long shadow. - A

pat/how-to-identify-pin-bar-setups.name: How to Identify Pin Bar Setups
pat/how-to-identify-pin-bar-setups.description: Trading is a game of probabilities. There is no certainty. You should evaluate your pin bar setups from multiple angles. Looking for quality setups means you are trying to put the probabilities of success in your favor.

pat/criteria-for-a-valid-pin-bar.name: Criteria for a Valid Pin Bar
pat/criteria-for-a-valid-pin-bar.description: 1. **Time Frame:** Pin bars formed in bigger time frames (4H, daily) should be taken into consideration. Smaller time frames generate too many false signals. 2. **Trend Direction:** A pin bar formed in line with the direction of the market is more powerful than one formed against the trend. Bullish

pat/psychology-behind-pin-bar-formation.name: Psychology Behind Pin Bar Formation
pat/psychology-behind-pin-bar-formation.description: Pin bars are formed when prices are rejected. This rejection alone does not indicate a reversal signal because pin bars can form everywhere on your chart. The most important areas to watch are: - **Support and resistance levels** - **Supply and demand zones** - **Moving averages** If the rejection o

pat/trading-pin-bars-with-the-trend.name: Trading Pin Bars With the Trend
pat/trading-pin-bars-with-the-trend.description: If you are a beginner trader, stick with the trend. Pin bars that occur in trending markets offer good trading opportunities with high risk/reward ratio.

pat/trading-pin-bars-with-confluence.name: Trading Pin Bars with Confluence
pat/trading-pin-bars-with-confluence.description: Confluence happens when multiple technical indicators generate the same signal. This concept is used by price action traders to filter entry points and spot high-probability signals.

pat/trading-pin-bars-in-range-bound-mark.name: Trading Pin Bars in Range-Bound Markets
pat/trading-pin-bars-in-range-bound-mark.description: A market is ranging when prices do not make any higher high and higher low and start trading horizontally between a definable level of support and a definable level of resistance.

pat/confirming-pin-bar-signals-with-boll.name: Confirming Pin Bar Signals with Bollinger Bands
pat/confirming-pin-bar-signals-with-boll.description: The Bollinger Bands indicator, developed by John Bollinger, measures a market's volatility and can be used as confirmation. **Strategy:** - Combine horizontal support and resistance with the upper and lower Bollinger Bands false breakout. - If prices are rejected from major key levels and from the b

pat/1-candlestick-pattern-confirmation-t.name: 1. Candlestick Pattern Confirmation Techniques
pat/1-candlestick-pattern-confirmation-t.description: Candlestick patterns alone are probabilistic signals, not certainties. Confirmation is the process of validating a pattern's prediction before committing capital. Research shows that patterns confirmed by at least one additional signal achieve success rates 15-25% higher than unconfirmed patterns.

pat/2-volume-confirmation-with-candle-pa.name: 2. Volume Confirmation with Candle Patterns
pat/2-volume-confirmation-with-candle-pa.description: Volume is arguably the most important confirmation tool for candlestick patterns. It reveals whether the price movement represented by the pattern has genuine institutional participation or is merely retail noise.

pat/reversal-patterns.name: Reversal Patterns
pat/reversal-patterns.description: - **The pattern candle (reversal candle) should have high volume.** This shows that the counter-trend force has arrived in strength. - **The preceding trend should show declining volume.** This indicates the existing trend is running out of steam. - **A volume spike on the reversal day is the strong

pat/continuation-patterns.name: Continuation Patterns
pat/continuation-patterns.description: - **Volume should decrease during the consolidation/correction phase.** Low volume during a pullback shows that the counter-trend move lacks conviction. - **Volume should increase on the breakout candle.** When the trend resumes, the surge in volume confirms genuine participation. **Example -- Risin

pat/indecision-patterns.name: Indecision Patterns
pat/indecision-patterns.description: - **High volume on a Doji = significant.** A Doji with high volume means both buyers and sellers fought hard. This often precedes a major move. - **Low volume on a Doji = insignificant.** A Doji with low volume is just a slow day. Ignore it.

pat/24-volume-divergence-patterns.name: 2.4 Volume Divergence Patterns
pat/24-volume-divergence-patterns.description: Volume divergence occurs when volume and price move in opposite directions, and it often precedes reversals. | Divergence | Price Action | Volume | Signal | |-----------|-------------|--------|--------| | **Bearish volume divergence** | Price making higher highs | Volume making lower highs | Uptrend

pat/3-candlestick-patterns-with-support-.name: 3. Candlestick Patterns with Support & Resistance
pat/3-candlestick-patterns-with-support-.description: Candlestick patterns at key support and resistance levels are dramatically more reliable than patterns appearing in "open space" (middle of a range). The combination of structural price levels with candlestick sentiment signals creates the highest-probability trading setups.

pat/31-why-sr-amplifies-pattern-reliabil.name: 3.1 Why S/R Amplifies Pattern Reliability
pat/31-why-sr-amplifies-pattern-reliabil.description: Support and resistance levels represent areas where supply and demand have historically been concentrated. When a candlestick pattern forms at these levels, it is reading the same supply/demand dynamics in real time: - **Pattern at support:** Buyers have historically defended this level. A bullish c

pat/45-timeframe-specific-pattern-behavi.description: Different timeframes exhibit different pattern reliability: | Timeframe | Pattern Reliability | Notes | |-----------|-------------------|-------| | Monthly | Highest | Rare patterns; extremely significant when they appear | | Weekly | Very High | Ideal for swing/position trading signals | | Daily |

pat/5-candlestick-patterns-in-different-.name: 5. Candlestick Patterns in Different Market Conditions
pat/5-candlestick-patterns-in-different-.description: The effectiveness of candlestick patterns varies significantly based on the prevailing market condition. A pattern that is highly reliable in a trending market may produce false signals in a ranging market.

pat/61-over-reliance-on-single-patterns.name: 6.1 Over-Reliance on Single Patterns
pat/61-over-reliance-on-single-patterns.description: **The Mistake:** Seeing a Hammer or Shooting Star and immediately entering a trade without any additional analysis. **Why It Fails:** A single candlestick pattern represents one session's price action out of thousands. In isolation, individual patterns have success rates only slightly above 50%. It

pat/65-confusing-visually-similar-patter.name: 6.5 Confusing Visually Similar Patterns
pat/65-confusing-visually-similar-patter.description: **The Mistake:** Misidentifying a Hanging Man as a Hammer, or a Shooting Star as an Inverted Hammer, because they look identical. **Why It Fails:** The same candlestick shape has completely different implications depending on where it appears in the trend: - Hammer (bullish) = Long lower wick at the

pat/68-expecting-perfect-textbook-patter.name: 6.8 Expecting Perfect Textbook Patterns
pat/68-expecting-perfect-textbook-patter.japanese_name: e.g., the engulfing candle is 1 tick short of fully engulfing, or the Morning Star gap is 0.01 instead of a "real" gap
pat/68-expecting-perfect-textbook-patter.description: **The Mistake:** Rejecting a pattern because it does not match the textbook illustration exactly (e.g., the engulfing candle is 1 tick short of fully engulfing, or the Morning Star gap is 0.01 instead of a "real" gap). **Why It Fails:** Real markets rarely produce perfect textbook patterns. The unde

pat/7-candlestick-patterns-vs-western-ch.name: 7. Candlestick Patterns vs Western Chart Patterns
pat/7-candlestick-patterns-vs-western-ch.description: Japanese candlestick patterns and Western chart patterns are complementary analytical tools with distinct characteristics. Understanding their differences and synergies allows traders to combine them for maximum effectiveness.

pat/73-pattern-correspondences.name: 7.3 Pattern Correspondences
pat/73-pattern-correspondences.description: Some Japanese candlestick patterns have direct Western chart pattern equivalents: | Japanese Candlestick | Western Equivalent | Notes | |---------------------|-------------------|-------| | Three Buddha Top (Sanzon) | Head and Shoulders | Central peak is highest | | Inverted Three Buddha | Inverse H

pat/candlestick-pattern-strengths.name: Candlestick Pattern Strengths
pat/candlestick-pattern-strengths.description: - **Faster signals:** Patterns form in 1-3 sessions, allowing quicker reaction. - **Sentiment visibility:** Open and close relationships reveal buyer/seller dynamics within each session. - **Rich vocabulary:** 60+ distinct patterns provide nuanced market readings. - **Works with Western tools:** Can

pat/candlestick-pattern-weaknesses.name: Candlestick Pattern Weaknesses
pat/candlestick-pattern-weaknesses.description: - **No built-in price targets:** Unlike Head and Shoulders or triangles, candlestick patterns do not provide measured move targets. - **Short prediction horizon:** Most effective within 10 days; lose predictive power beyond that. - **Higher false signal rate:** Short-term patterns are more susceptib

pat/western-chart-pattern-strengths.name: Western Chart Pattern Strengths
pat/western-chart-pattern-strengths.description: - **Built-in price targets:** Measured move from the pattern height provides clear targets. - **Longer-term relevance:** Patterns spanning weeks/months capture broader market structure. - **Lower false signal rate:** Longer formation filters short-term noise. - **Trend confirmation:** Patterns like

pat/western-chart-pattern-weaknesses.name: Western Chart Pattern Weaknesses
pat/western-chart-pattern-weaknesses.description: - **Slow signal generation:** Waiting for a Head and Shoulders to complete can take weeks or months. - **Late entries:** By the time the neckline breaks, a significant move may have already occurred. - **Limited intra-session insight:** Bar charts and line charts do not reveal intra-session dynamics

strat/how-to-trade-trending-markets.name: How to Trade Trending Markets
strat/how-to-trade-trending-markets.description: If you identify a **bullish market**, look for a **buying opportunity** (trade with the trend). If the market is **bearish**, look for a **selling opportunity**.

strat/three-ways-to-trade-ranging-market.name: Three Ways to Trade Ranging Markets

strat/1-trade-from-boundaries.name: 1. Trade from Boundaries
strat/1-trade-from-boundaries.description: - Wait for price to approach support or resistance level. - Buy at key support and sell at key resistance. - The best buying and selling opportunities occur at these key levels.

strat/2-trade-the-breakout.name: 2. Trade the Breakout
strat/2-trade-the-breakout.description: - Wait for the breakout from either the support or the resistance level. - The breakout means the ranging period is over and a new trend will begin. - The best way to enter is **after the breakout**. - **Warning:** Range boundaries are often overshot, giving the illusion a breakout is occurring. Thi

strat/3-trade-the-pullback-after-breakou.name: 3. Trade the Pullback After Breakout
strat/3-trade-the-pullback-after-breakou.description: - Wait for a pullback after the breakout of support or resistance. - After the breakout, the market may come back to retest the broken level (resistance becomes support, or support becomes resistance) before continuing. - The pullback is your second chance to join the trend if you missed the breakou

strat/before-every-trade.name: Before Every Trade
strat/before-every-trade.description: 1. Calculate how much you may **win**. 2. Calculate how much you may **lose**. 3. Place your **stop loss order**. 4. Place your **profit target**. 5. **Forget about your trade.** Let the market tell you if you are right or wrong. ---

strat/entry.name: Entry
strat/entry.description: 1. Identify the **trend** (uptrend, downtrend, or ranging). 2. Identify the **level** (support, resistance, S&D zones, Fibonacci, MA). 3. Wait for the **signal** (pin bar, engulfing bar, inside bar, or inside bar false breakout). 4. Confirm with **confluence** (multiple factors pointing the same dir

strat/exit.name: Exit
strat/exit.description: 1. **Stop loss:** Placed at the pattern-specific location (see table above). 2. **Profit target:** The next support or resistance level. 3. **Set and forget:** Do not micromanage. Let the market do the work.

strat/how-to-trade-the-engulfing-bar-thr.name: How to Trade the Engulfing Bar: Three Elements

strat/how-traders-use-moving-averages.name: How Traders Use Moving Averages
strat/how-traders-use-moving-averages.description: - **Trend following tool:** Buy when prices are above the 200 SMA; sell when below. - **Overbought/oversold:** If prices move far from the MAs in an uptrend, the market is overbought. - **Trend change prediction:** Using the crossover strategy -- if one MA crosses over another, it signals a trend re

strat/the-strategy.name: The Strategy
strat/the-strategy.description: 1. Identify a **strong trend**. 2. Wait for the formation of an inside bar pattern **in line with the direction of the market**. 3. The formation indicates the market pauses before making its next move, allowing you to enter at the right time.

strat/the-strategy-3.name: The Strategy
strat/the-strategy-3.description: 1. Define a clear uptrend or downtrend. 2. Define major corrective levels using the Fibonacci retracement tool. 3. If you see an engulfing bar pattern matching up with the **50% or 61% levels**, it is a powerful price action trading signal.

strat/the-strategy-4.name: The Strategy
strat/the-strategy-4.description: - By connecting the extreme highs, you create a trend line acting as a **resistance level**. The formation of an engulfing bar pattern at this level shows a good selling opportunity. - By connecting the extreme lows, the trend line acts as a **support level**. The formation of an engulfing bar at th

strat/strategy-1-trade-from-support-and-.name: Strategy 1: Trade from Support and Resistance
strat/strategy-1-trade-from-support-and-.description: Buy at the support level and sell at the resistance level when an engulfing bar forms at these boundaries.

strat/strategy-2-trade-the-breakout-or-p.name: Strategy 2: Trade the Breakout (or Pullback)
strat/strategy-2-trade-the-breakout-or-p.description: - Trade the breakout of the range. - Or wait for the pullback after the breakout, then enter.

strat/strategy-3-trade-the-false-breakou.name: Strategy 3: Trade the False Breakout
strat/strategy-3-trade-the-false-breakou.description: False breakouts are one of the most powerful price action strategies. They occur in all types of markets. - If you know how to use false breakouts in combination with the engulfing bar pattern at a major support or resistance level, you will buy the bottoms and sell the tops intelligently. - A false

strat/the-strategy-8.name: The Strategy
strat/the-strategy-8.description: - Identify quality supply or demand zones. - Wait for an engulfing bar to form at these zones. - The formation of an engulfing bar is a clear signal that sellers (at supply) or buyers (at demand) are still willing to trade from the same price level. - The secret behind supply and demand areas is tha

strat/money-management-rules-for-engulfi.name: Money Management Rules for Engulfing Bar Trades
strat/money-management-rules-for-engulfi.description: Not all engulfing bar patterns are worth trading. Price action signals with low risk/reward ratios should be ignored.

strat/entry-and-exit-rules.name: Entry and Exit Rules
strat/entry-and-exit-rules.description: 1. When you identify an engulfing bar pattern and all conditions are in place, **take an order immediately** after the signal forms. 2. **Stop loss:** Below the candlestick pattern (for buys) or above (for sells). 3. **Profit target:** The next support or resistance level. 4. Once you set your prote

strat/how-to-trade-inside-bars-in-trendi.name: How to Trade Inside Bars in Trending Markets
strat/how-to-trade-inside-bars-in-trendi.description: The inside bar can be traded successfully in trending markets, particularly when the market is moving strongly.

strat/entry-rules.name: Entry Rules
strat/entry-rules.description: - Place an order **after the breakout of the pattern** (after price breaks below the mother candle in a downtrend, or above in an uptrend). - **Stop loss:** Above the mother candle (for sells) or below it (for buys). - **Profit target:** The next support or resistance level.

strat/tips-on-trading-inside-bar-setups.name: Tips on Trading Inside Bar Setups

strat/1-trade-bigger-time-frames.name: 1. Trade Bigger Time Frames
strat/1-trade-bigger-time-frames.description: - If you are a beginner, stick with the **daily and 4-hour time frame**. - Trading on lower time frames increases the chance to overtrade and take low-probability signals, which is the quickest way to blow up your account. - Focusing on bigger time frames allows you to **set and forget** your trade

strat/2-trade-the-dominant-trend.name: 2. Trade the Dominant Trend
strat/2-trade-the-dominant-trend.description: - Start trading inside bars **in line with the market direction**, especially in a strong bullish or bearish trend. - Never try to trade it against the trend if you are a beginner. - When you master trading with the trend, you can move to trade range-bound markets and counter-trends.

strat/3-trade-only-from-key-levels.name: 3. Trade Only from Key Levels
strat/3-trade-only-from-key-levels.description: - Not all inside bars are worth your money. - There are **specific locations** where this setup works great. - Make sure your signal is located at a **key level** in the market.

strat/the-strategy-7.name: The Strategy
strat/the-strategy-7.description: In an uptrend or downtrend, the market creates impulsive moves and pullbacks. The Fibonacci retracement helps highlight the most important pullback levels. 1. Select the Fibonacci tool on your chart. 2. If the market moves strongly, wait for retracements. 3. If the pullback reaches **50% or 61%** le

strat/how-to-identify-pin-bar-setups.name: How to Identify Pin Bar Setups
strat/how-to-identify-pin-bar-setups.description: Trading is a game of probabilities. There is no certainty. You should evaluate your pin bar setups from multiple angles. Looking for quality setups means you are trying to put the probabilities of success in your favor.

strat/strategy.name: Strategy
strat/strategy.description: 1. Identify a clear uptrend or downtrend. 2. Wait for a pin bar to occur after a pullback to support or resistance level.

strat/example-criteria-for-a-high-qualit.name: Example Criteria for a High-Quality Setup
strat/example-criteria-for-a-high-qualit.description: 1. The pin bar is well formed and in line with the direction of the market. 2. The rejection occurred at a major key level (a hot point in the market). 3. The risk-to-reward ratio is good and worth trading.

strat/1-aggressive-entry.name: 1. Aggressive Entry
strat/1-aggressive-entry.description: Enter the market **immediately after the pin bar closes** without waiting for confirmation. - This helps you catch the move from the beginning, since sometimes the price goes in your direction right after the close. - **Stop loss:** Above the long tail (for sell) or below the long tail (for buy). -

strat/2-conservative-entry.name: 2. Conservative Entry
strat/2-conservative-entry.description: Enter the market after a **50% retracement of the pin bar range**. - This strategy sometimes gives you more than **5:1 risk/reward ratio**. - However, sometimes the market will leave without you because it does not retrace to 50%. - **Advantage:** Decreases risk and increases reward. - **Disadvantag

strat/strategy-1-trade-from-boundaries.name: Strategy 1: Trade from Boundaries
strat/strategy-1-trade-from-boundaries.description: - Buy at the support level and sell at the resistance level. - Wait for a clear price action setup such as a pin bar. **Entry Rules:** 1. A pin bar rejected from the support level -- buy after the pin bar closes, or wait for a 50% retracement of the pin bar range. 2. Stop loss below the support leve

strat/strategy-2-trade-the-breakout-dire.name: Strategy 2: Trade the Breakout Direction
strat/strategy-2-trade-the-breakout-dire.description: - Trade in the direction of breakouts from major key levels. - Or wait for prices to retrace back to the breakout point and then enter. - After breakout, wait for a pin bar at the retest level.
